item.title: A Cryptography Policy Framework for Electronic Commerce: Building Canada's Information Economy and Society
Canada's Quiet Weakening of Communications Encryption
item.description: Authors: Christopher Parsons, Tamir Israel Published: August 2015 URL: https://citizenlab.ca/2015/08/canadas-quiet-history-of-weakening-communications-encryption/ Tags: 2010s Canada Abstract: This article outlines some of the federal government of Canada’s successful and unsuccessful attempts to weaken encryption standards.

item.title: Canada’s New and Irresponsible Encryption Policy: How the Government of Canada’s New Policy Threatens Charter Rights, Cybersecurity, Economic Growth, and Foreign Policy
item.description: Authors: Christopher Parsons Published: August 2019 URL: https://citizenlab.ca/2019/08/canadas-new-and-irresponsible-encryption-policy-how-the-government-of-canadas-new-policy-threatens-charter-rights-cybersecurity-economic-growth-and-foreign-policy/ Tags: 2010s Canada Five Eyes Abstract: The proposed rationales for weakening encryption would result in significant loses to Canadians’ abilities to exercise their rights and freedoms.

item.title: Encryption Policy a Crowd Pleaser
item.description: Authors: Jeff Leiper Published: November 1998 URL: http://search.proquest.com/docview/217686754?pq-origsite=summon Tags: 1990s Canada Abstract: At a meeting earlier this year by concerned industry players, the government was told that proposed restrictions were impractical because criminals had access to offshore encryption products. Further, the wait for a concrete policy was hurting business because companies were unsure of what they’d be allowed to sell. Shipping delays were costing money, officials from companies like kyberpass Corp.

item.title: The Five Eyes Statement on Encryption: Things Are Seldom What They Seem
item.description: Published: September 2018 URL: https://www.lawfareblog.com/five-eyes-statement-encryption-things-are-seldom-what-they-seem Tags: 2010s Canada Five Eyes Law Enforcement NZ Abstract: Earlier this September, law enforcement officials from the Five Eyes intelligence alliance—made up of Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States—met in Australia and issued a Statement of Principles on Access to Evidence and Encryption.
